timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Actually I want to have this hard coded, since we should also be able to do upgrade from pre-previous version if we are really backwards compatible. So ideally we should have tests which starts on the last supported and be able to upgrade to the newest.
replies.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: Do you mean skip minor versions (e.g. 0.23 to 0.25) or do you mean skip micro versions (0.23.x to 0.24.x)? So far we've never discussed that skipping versions was a possibility.
replies.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: I mean if we say we are backwards compatible this is implicit that this is possible.
replies.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: We typically say we're backwards compatible from one version to the other, I've never heard any mention that we also are with older versions. Was this something that was decided a while back?
replies.author: npepinpe

timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: this method was copied btw from your branch :D
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: Is this necessary always? It's really only useful when debugging, no? And the container state rule should output logs of containers when the test fails, so we probably only need that.
timeline.author: npepinpe
npepinpe

timeline.message: fix(atomix): fix backwards compatibilty issue with RaftNamespace

test(upgrade-test): add rolling update test

 * The first test a totally simple and only test that we are able to
   upgrade a node and start the new version without problems. Later we
   can add more sophisticated tests.
fix(atomix): fix backwards compatibilty issue with RaftNamespace
fix(atomix): fix backwards compatibilty issue with RaftNamespace
